questions.text: Which of the following respiratory system components is derived from neural crest?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Laryngeal cartilage 
Ref– Read the text below
Sol:
•    Laryngeal cartilages (e.g., the thyroid, cricoid, arytenoid cartilages) are derived from neural crest. 
•    The endothelial cells in the simple squamous epithelium that lines the pulmonary capillaries are derived from visceral mesoderm.
•    The epithelial lining of primary bronchi is derived from endoderm.
•    Tracheal glands and epithelium both derive from endoderm.

questions.text: A mother with diabetes gives birth to a baby who is diagnosed as having dextroposition of the aorta and the pulmonary trunk with cyanosis and shortness of breath. Which of the following structure& la required to remain patent until surgical correction of the deformity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ductus arteriosus

Dextroposition or transposition of the great arteries must be accompanied by a VSD or a patent ductus arteriosus for the infant to survive. The transposition causes oxygenated blood to pass from the left ventricle into the pulmonary trunk and then into the lungs, but deoxygenated blood travels from the right ventricle into the aorta and then into the systemic circulation.

questions.text: 1- year-old male is found to have high blood pressure, normal genitalia on physical examination, low serum aldosterone and high serum testosterone. Which of the following is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This patient is most likely suffering from congenital 11 β-hydroxylase deficiency. 11- β- hydroxylase deficiency leads to the inability to synthesize aldosterone with a buildup of the mineralocorticoid 11-deoxycorticosterone.

11- β hydroxylase deficiency is a form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. The enzyme responsible for converting 11-deoxycorticosterone into aldosterone and 11-deoxycortisol into cortisol. A deficiency results in low levels of cortisol and high levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone which has mineralocorticoid activity and is responsible for the hypertension seen in this patient. Furthermore, sex hormones such as testosterone become elevated as cortisol precursors are diverted toward the androgen synthesis pathway. Male patients with 11-hydroxylase deficiency consequently have normal genitalia at birth, while females have ambiguous genitalia.
Incorrect answers:

Answer A: 17-hydroxylase deficiency presents in a male with ambiguous genitalia due to decreased production of testosterone.

Answer B: 21-hydroxylase deficiency presents with low levels of serum mineralocorticoids and low blood pressure. Testosterone would also be elevated in this case.

Answer C: This patient is suffering from a deficiency of 11-hydroxylase and, thus, we would not expect 11-hydroxylase to be elevated.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with congestive heart failure is being treated with furosemide for volume overload. On follow-up, he complains of muscle weakness and cramps. Blood tests reveal hypokalemia. Which of the following agents, when added to his regimen, would best help prevent further potassium loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Amiloride
 Explanation:
Furosemide, a loop diuretic, inhibits the Na⁺/K⁺/2Cl⁻ cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. While effective at mobilizing fluid, it also promotes significant potassium and magnesium loss, leading to hypokalemia.
•    Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that works by blocking epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in the distal nephron, thereby reducing sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion.
•    It prevents further K⁺ loss, making it an ideal agent to combine with loop or thiazide diuretics when hypokalemia is a concern.
Other option analysis
A. Thiazide – Also causes potassium loss; would worsen hypokalemia
B. Acetazolamide – Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor; mild diuretic, also causes K⁺ loss
D. Mannitol – Osmotic diuretic; does not conserve K⁺, and not suitable for this scenario

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with schizophrenia is being considered for antipsychotic therapy. His treating physician is particularly concerned about the risk of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), given the patient's history of movement disorders. Which of the following antipsychotic medications is associated with the lowest risk of developing EPS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Clozapine
Explanation:
Extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) are drug-induced movement disorders that include dystonia, akathisia, parkinsonism, and tardive dyskinesia. These are most commonly caused by dopamine D2 receptor blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway.
Antipsychotics & EPS Risk:
•    Typical (first-generation) antipsychotics like haloperidol are strong D2 antagonists and carry a high risk of EPS.
•    Atypical (second-generation) antipsychotics generally have lower D2 antagonism and higher 5-HT2A antagonism, which reduces EPS risk.
? Clozapine:
•    It is a unique atypical antipsychotic with minimal D2 antagonism and high 5-HT2A blockade.
•    It has the lowest risk of EPS among all antipsychotics.
•    Reserved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia due to risk of agranulocytosis, seizures, and myocarditis.
Other options analysis-
A. Haloperidol – Strong D2 blocker → high EPS risk 
B. Risperidone – Atypical, but EPS risk is dose-dependent (moderate at high doses) 
C. Olanzapine – Lower EPS risk than typicals but not the lowest

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the clinic with complaints of frequent episodes of sudden staring, lip smacking, and brief unresponsiveness lasting for a few seconds. The EEG reveals 3-Hz spike-and-wave discharges.  Which of the following is the preferred drug for treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ethosuximide
Explanation:
Absence seizures (formerly called petit mal) are generalized non-convulsive seizures most commonly seen in children. The hallmark features include: •  Sudden onset and sudden cessation- Brief loss of consciousness, No postictal confusion & Classic 3 Hz spike-and-wave pattern on EEG
Mechanism of Ethosuximide:
•    Ethosuximide selectively blocks T-type calcium channels in thalamic neurons, which are crucial for generating the rhythmic 3-Hz spike-and-wave discharges seen in absence seizures.
Other options analysis-
A. Carbamazepine – Worsens absence seizures; used for focal and generalized tonic-clonic seizures
B. Phenytoin – Ineffective for absence; used in generalized tonic-clonic and focal seizures
C. Valproic acid – Broad-spectrum; can be used if absence seizures occur along with tonic-clonic or myoclonic seizures

questions.text: A young woman diagnosed with an uncomplicated urinary tract infection was started on empirical antibiotic therapy. After a few days, she reports heel pain and difficulty walking. On examination, tenderness is noted over the Achilles tendon, raising suspicion of tendinitis. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the most likely causative antibiotic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Inhibits DNA gyrase
Explanation:
The clinical presentation — Achilles tendinitis following antibiotic use — is a characteristic adverse effect of fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin), which are commonly used to treat UTIs.
Fluoroquinolones act by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase (topoisomerase II) and topoisomerase IV, enzymes critical for supercoiling and replication of bacterial DNA. This results in the cessation of bacterial DNA replication and ultimately bacterial death.
•    Tendinitis and tendon rupture, especially of the Achilles tendon, are known adverse effects of fluoroquinolones, particularly in the elderly, patients on corticosteroids, or athletes — but can occasionally occur in young healthy individuals as well.
•    The adverse effect is not related to the mechanism of host microtubule inhibition or protein synthesis interference but is likely due to degenerative effects on collagen and tendon matrix proteins.

questions.text: A patient undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer develops symptoms of ringing in the ears, along with decreased urine output . Which of the following agents is used as a cytoprotective antidote to prevent renal damage associated with this anticancer drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Amifostine
Explanation:
The clinical scenario suggests cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity — two of its most notorious adverse effects. Cisplatin is a platinum-based chemotherapeutic agent commonly used in solid tumors, including breast, testicular, ovarian, and bladder cancers.
•    Amifostine is a cytoprotective agent that scavenges free radicals and protects normal tissues, particularly the kidneys and salivary glands, from the toxic effects of cisplatin.
•    It is selectively taken up by normal tissues due to higher levels of alkaline phosphatase, which activates the prodrug to its active thiol form.
Other options analysis
A. MESNA – Used to prevent hemorrhagic cystitis caused by cyclophosphamide/ifosfamide
B. Leucovorin – Rescue agent for methotrexate toxicity
D. Oprelvekin – IL-11 analog used to prevent thrombocytopenia in chemotherapy patients

questions.text: A neutropenic patient with fever is started on amphotericin B. What is the major limiting toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Nephrotoxicity
Explanation:
Amphotericin B is a broad-spectrum polyene antifungal used for serious systemic mycoses, especially in immunocompromised or neutropenic patients. It binds to ergosterol in fungal cell membranes, forming pores that cause leakage and cell death.
However, its clinical use is often limited due to dose-dependent nephrotoxicity, the most important and limiting adverse effect.
Other options analysis- 
 A. Hepatotoxicity – More common with azoles, not amphotericin B
 B. Bone marrow suppression – Seen with flucytosine
D. Pulmonary fibrosis – Associated with drugs like bleomycin, not antifungals

questions.text: A 45-year-old male renal transplant recipient presents with progressive gingival overgrowth and increased serum creatinine levels during a routine follow-up. His immunosuppressive regimen includes a calcineurin inhibitor, an antiproliferative agent, and low-dose corticosteroids. He denies nonadherence. Which of the following drugs in his regimen is most likely responsible for both his current findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cyclosporine

Explanation:
This patient is exhibiting gingival hyperplasia and nephrotoxicity, both hallmark adverse effects of cyclosporine, a calcineurin inhibitor used extensively in transplant recipients to prevent rejection.
•    Cyclosporine causes dose-dependent nephrotoxicity via vasoconstriction of afferent arterioles.
•    It also causes gingival hyperplasia, a side effect shared with phenytoin and nifedipine.
•    Tacrolimus, another calcineurin inhibitor, also causes nephrotoxicity but is not associated with gum hypertrophy, which helps distinguish the 

Other options analysis- 
A. Azathioprine – Bone marrow suppression; not associated with nephrotoxicity or gum changes
B. Mycophenolate – GI side effects, bone marrow suppression; no gingival hyperplasia or nephrotoxicity
D. Tacrolimus – Causes nephrotoxicity, tremor, hyperglycemia; no gum hypertrophy

questions.text: A researcher is studying the bacterial growth curve of Escherichia coli. During which phase of growth are antibiotics targeting cell wall synthesis most effective?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The log phase is characterized by rapid bacterial division, making the bacteria most susceptible to antibiotics like beta-lactams (penicillins, cephalosporins), which target actively growing and dividing cells. 

The lag phase involves adaptation, and the stationary phase occurs when nutrients are depleted.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with high fever, jaundice, and conjunctival suffusion. He recently swam in floodwater. Laboratory findings show elevated creatinine, bilirubin, and transaminases. Which of the following is the most likely selective medium for this pathogen?

Correct Answer (D)

It is transmitted via contaminated water (rat urine) and presents with conjunctival suffusion (red but non-purulent eyes), a key diagnostic clue.

Selective medium is EMJH medium.

questions.text: Most common fracture seen in road traffic accidents is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Linear fracture

A linear fracture is the most common fracture seen in road traffic accidents, especially when the impact is direct and linear (such as a direct blow or a collision). This type of fracture can occur in the skull, limbs, or other areas and involves a crack that runs straight along the bone. It is a common injury in accidents due to the forceful impact.

Incorrect options:

A. Hinge fracture
A hinge fracture refers to a specific type of fracture around the elbow joint, where the bone typically breaks in such a way that it behaves like a hinge, but it's not typically associated with road traffic accidents. It is less common in such incidents.

C. Depressed fracture
A depressed fracture typically involves the skull, where a section of the skull is pushed inward. While this can occur in some severe accidents, it's not as common as linear fractures, especially in less severe collisions or in cases involving only limb injuries.

D. Gutter fracture
A gutter fracture is a type of bone injury where the fracture runs along the surface, resembling a gutter or channel. It's typically seen in specific areas like the skull but is less common compared to linear fractures in RTAs.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries must also be considered for ligation if epistaxis persists after TELSPA?

Anterior ethmoidal artery
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
•    If epistaxis persists after TELSPA, the anterior ethmoidal artery (AEA) should be assessed because:
o    It supplies the superior part of the nasal septum and anterior nasal cavity.
o    It originates from the ophthalmic artery (branch of internal carotid artery), so it is not controlled by sphenopalatine artery ligation.
•    Internal carotid artery (A) ligation is not performed unless in cases of severe trauma.
•    Superior thyroid artery (C) and external jugular artery (D) are unrelated to nasal vascular supply.

Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
•    Juvenile papillomas of larynx= recurrent respiratory papillomatosis is caused by HPV-6,11. The infection is transmitted from mother at the time of birth. They can spread downwards to trachea bronchi lungs.
•    Peak incidence of juvenile type is between the age of 3 and 5 years 
•    HPV 11 and 6  are commonly associated
•    Interferon alpha-2a has shown promising results
•    Typically seen in young children with chronic hoarseness and +- respiratory distress.
•    CO2 laser is the treatment of choice. 
•    Recurrences are common after surgery. They are premalignant
•    Interferon alpha and intralesional cidofovir is helpful in management.
•    All papillomas should be examined histo- pathologically to exclude any dysplastic features or malignant transformation.

questions.text: A patient has intact otoacoustic emissions and absent wave V on the ABR. Which condition does this patient have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Auditory neuropathy
Ref: Read the text below.

AUDITORY NEUROPATHY (AUDITORY DYSSYNCHRONY)
    Not a problem with the cochlea/hair cells but more of a problem with the cochlear nerve
    Absent wave V on ABR and present OAEs

questions.text: A patient of right unsafe CSOM has presented with history of diplopia and pain behind the right eye. What is the further ideal investigation in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

HRCT temporal bone.
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
•    Petrous apex may be pneumatized in about 30% cases with connecting cell tracts from the mastoid. 
•    This may hence predispose to spread of infection to the petrous apex from middle ear suppuration.
•    There is secondary involvement of Vth and VIth cranial nerves which are closely related to the petrous apex.
Gradenigo’s syndrome 
•    The triad of otorrhoea, retro orbital pain ( due to Trigeminal neuealgia) and diplopia ( Lateral Rectus palsy due to Abducent nerve involvent ) in apical petrositis is known as Gradenigo’s Syndrome.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with sudden onset of severe vertigo, nausea, vomiting, and horizontal nystagmus that suppresses with visual fixation. He denies hearing loss. Neurological examination is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vestibular neuritis
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
•    Vestibular neuritis is an acute disorder of the vestibular nerve, often post-viral, causing severe vertigo, nausea, and nystagmus without hearing loss. 
•    Visual fixation suppresses peripheral vestibular nystagmus. 
•    Absence of neurological signs helps differentiate it from a central cause like a stroke.

choices.text: Injury to the external carotid artery

questions.text: A 7-year-old child undergoes tonsillectomy and develops postoperative bleeding on Day 7. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Infection of the tonsillar fossa
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
•    Secondary hemorrhage (bleeding after 24 hours, often around Day 5–10) is usually due to infection of the healing tonsillar fossa, which erodes blood vessels. 
•    Primary hemorrhage (within 24 hours) is usually due to a surgical issue like ligature slippage.

questions.text: A 5 year old patient presents with the history of hearing loss. On examination he is found to have a chalky white mass behind the intact tympanic membrane as shown in the image . What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Congenital cholesteatoma
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
•    Congenital cholesteatomas are believed to arise from embryonal inclusions or rests of epithelial cells.  
•    Levenson, established a set of criteria for the definition of congenital cholesteatoma in the middle ear.  
•    These criteria included, (1) a white mass medial to a normal tympanic membrane, (2) a normal pars flaccida and pars tensa, (3) no prior otologic procedures. In addition, prior bouts of otitis media were not grounds for exclusion.

questions.text: Choose the most appropriate statement regarding “Indirect Larygoscopy “
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Laryngeal mirror held firmly against the uvula and soft palate.
Sol:-
Laryngeal mirror (size 4–6) which has been warmed and tested on the back of hand is introduced into the mouth and held firmly against the uvula and soft palate

                                           
STRUCTURES SEEN ON INDIRECT LARYNGOSCOPY 
Indirect laryngoscopy permits examination of structures of the oropharynx, larynx and laryngopharynx.
He is asked to protrude his tongue which is wrapped in gauze and held by the examiner between the thumb and middle finger. Index finger is used to keep the upper lip or moustache out of the way
• Larynx. Epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, arytenoids, cuneiform and corniculate cartilages, ventricular bands,ventricles, true cords, anterior commissure, posterior commissure, subglottis and rings of trachea.
• Laryngopharynx. Both pyriform fossae, postcricoid region, posterior wall of laryngopharynx.
• Oropharynx. Base of tongue, lingual tonsils, valleculae, medial and lateral glossoepiglottic folds.

Wood industry exposure leads to squamous cell carcinoma of sinuses.

questions.text: 75-year-old man with right-sided face pain revealed a mass in the maxillary sinus  (Study the given Fig). A large incisional biopsy from the nasal cavity concluded the diagnosis of sinus malignancy.Which of the following statement is correct  ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Squamous cell carcinomas of sinuses are more common in nickel industry workers.
Ref:Read the text below.
Sol:-
•    Ohngren’s line is from medial canthus of the eye to the angle of mandible.
•    Weber Fergusson incision is used for total maxillectomy.
•    This line divides maxilla into superstructure and infrastructure.
•    The malignancy of superstructure has poor prognosis due to proximity to orbit.
•    In woodworker’s the adenocarcinomas are more common and that too of ethmoid sinus.
•    In total maxillary sinus is the most common sinus to develop malignancy. 
•    In nickel exposed patents, the most common malignancy is squamous cell carcinoma.

Photophobia can also be present due to irritation of nerves

Fundoscopy/Indirect ophthalmoscopy Binocular test

A- left ciliary ganglion: lesion will cause Adie pupil

questions.text: The laser used for ablation of cornea in Laser in situ keratomileusis is a type of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Photoablative laser – excimer 193 nm

Myopia is corrected by central ablative flattening, and hypermetropia by ablation of the periphery so that the centre becomes steeper. LASIK can generally be used to treat hypermetropia up to 4 D, astigmatism up to 5 D and myopia up to 12 D depending on initial corneal thickness.

choices.text: Dilates pupil and helps in posterior segment evaluation

questions.text: Which of the following is not advantage of using cycloplegics in a patient with anterior uveitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cycloplegics are adjuvant in anterior uveitis as they reduce pain by reducing ciliary body spasm.

questions.text: Which of these syndrome is related to proptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Idiopathic granulomatous inflammation of orbital apex causing proptosis

questions.text: This procedure is done for?

Correct Answer (B)

Suturing the two eyelids is called tarsorapphy
Done in lag-ophthalmous, exposure keratitis (7th nerve palsy)

choices.text: Start aspirin and monitor in stroke unit

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with sudden onset right-sided weakness and aphasia. MRI brain shows acute infarct in the left MCA territory. CT angiogram shows proximal M1 occlusion. NIHSS score is 18. He presented to the hospital 5 hours after symptom onset. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Proceed with mechanical thrombectomy
Explanation: This patient has an acute ischemic stroke with a large vessel occlusion (LVO) in the M1 segment of MCA. He presented within 6 hours and is a candidate for mechanical thrombectomy, which is strongly indicated in LVOs if within 6 hours, and possibly up to 24 hours depending on perfusion imaging.
•    A. Aspirin and monitor: Conservative management is not appropriate for LVO with NIHSS 18.
•    B. IV alteplase: Thrombolysis is only effective up to 4.5 hours. This patient is beyond 4.5 hours.
•    D. Mannitol and hyperventilation: Used for raised ICP or herniation, which is not described here.

choices.text: Start empiric antibiotics and lumbar puncture
Observe for 24 hours and repeat clinical exam

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with fever, headache, and photophobia. On examination, he has neck stiffness and a positive Kernig's sign. He is drowsy but arousable. Fundoscopy shows papilledema. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Perform brain imaging before LP
Explanation: In suspected meningitis, LP is essential, but if signs of raised intracranial pressure (ICP) or focal neurological deficits are present (e.g., papilledema, altered sensorium), imaging must precede LP to avoid risk of herniation.
•    A. Start empiric antibiotics and LP: Antibiotics can be started but LP without prior imaging is contraindicated in this scenario.
•    B. LP first: Dangerous due to risk of brain herniation.
•    D. Observation delays both diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old alcoholic presents with burning pain and numbness in both feet. Examination reveals decreased vibration and pinprick sensation in a stocking distribution, and absent ankle jerks. Which nerve fibers are most involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Both small and large fibers
Explanation: Alcoholic neuropathy is a length-dependent axonal polyneuropathy that affects both small and large fibers.
•    Large fibers → vibration, proprioception, reflexes
•    Small fibers → pain, temperature
•    A. Large myelinated A-alpha fibers: Only accounts for proprioceptive loss, not pain.
•    B. C fibers: Only pain and temperature.
•    C. A-delta fibers: Pain and cold — but not vibration loss.
•    Hence, D is correct.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with ptosis and diplopia that worsens by evening. No limb weakness is present. Tensilon test is positive. Which test is most specific to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acetylcholine receptor antibody assay
Explanation: AChR antibody is highly specific for Myasthenia Gravis (MG) and is positive in 80–90% of generalized MG and ~50% of ocular MG.
•    B. CT chest: Useful to detect thymoma, but not diagnostic of MG.
•    C. Repetitive nerve stimulation: Shows decremental response but is less specific.
•    D. Muscle biopsy: Not helpful in MG — more useful in myopathies.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with known heart failure (EF 30%) presents with increasing dyspnea and bilateral leg swelling. BP is 100/60 mmHg, JVP is elevated, bilateral crepitations are present. Which medication should be avoided in this patient during decompensation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Beta-blocker
Explanation: In acute decompensated heart failure, beta-blockers can worsen cardiac output and are often held temporarily until the patient is hemodynamically stable. Once stable, they can be restarted for long-term benefit.
•    A. Furosemide: Indicated for volume overload.
•    B. Spironolactone: Beneficial unless severe hyperkalemia or renal failure.
•    D. Dobutamine: Positive inotrope, useful in low output HF.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a mid-diastolic murmur at the apex and variable S1intensity presents with worsening dyspnea and palpitations. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which valvular lesion is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mitral stenosis
Explanation: Mitral stenosis presents with:
•    Mid-diastolic murmur (best heard with bell at apex)
•    Loud S1 (due to forceful closure of stenotic valve)
•    High left atrial pressure → leads to atrial fibrillation
•    A. Aortic stenosis: Systolic murmur, radiates to carotids
•    C. Aortic regurgitation: Early diastolic murmur along left sternal border
•    D. Mitral regurgitation: Holosystolic murmur at apex radiating to axilla

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with right heart failure has elevated JVP with a prominent "v" wave and absent x descent. Which is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tricuspid regurgitation
Explanation: A prominent “v” wave and absent x descent in JVP is classic for tricuspid regurgitation, due to systolic backflow of blood into the right atrium.
•    A. Constrictive pericarditis: Shows rapid y descent, and prominent x descent
•    C. PE: JVP may be elevated, but v wave not prominent
•    D. Tamponade: JVP is elevated but waveform is blunted

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with chest pain for 5 hours. ECG shows ST elevation in V2-V5. Which of the following is most urgent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Immediate reperfusion therapy

Explanation: This is anterior wall STEMI (V2–V5). Time is myocardium — reperfusion therapy (PCI preferred within 90 mins or fibrinolysis if not available) is most urgent.

•    A. Morphine and nitrates: Symptomatic, not definitive

•    B. Heparin: Adjunct therapy

•    C. Beta-blockers: Avoided acutely in hemodynamic instability

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated JVP. ECG shows low voltage and electrical alternans. What is the most immediate step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Perform emergent pericardiocentesis
Explanation: This is cardiac tamponade (Beck’s triad + electrical alternans). The treatment is emergent pericardiocentesis to relieve pressure and restore cardiac output.
•    A. Diuretics: Worsen hypotension
•    B. Steroids: Used in pericarditis, not for tamponade
•    D. CT chest: Not required for diagnosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is found to have BP of 180/110 mmHg on multiple readings. He has episodes of palpitations, headache, and sweating. ECG is normal. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Measure plasma metanephrines
Explanation: Young patient + paroxysmal hypertension + classic triad (sweating, palpitations, headache) → suggests pheochromocytoma. Best initial test: plasma free metanephrines.
•    A. Amlodipine: Treating blindly may worsen crisis
•    B. Beta-blockers alone: Dangerous; unopposed alpha stimulation can worsen BP
•    D. Urinary sodium: Not diagnostic in this context

questions.text: A 76-year-old male with a history of hypertension and CAD presents with palpitations and light-headedness. ECG shows wide complex tachycardia at 180 bpm with fusion beats. BP is 110/70 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ventricular tachycardia
Explanation: In an elderly patient with structural heart disease, wide complex tachycardia with fusion beats strongly suggests ventricular tachycardia (VT).
•    A. SVT with aberrancy: Possible but less likely with fusion beats and CAD history.
•    C. AF with WPW: Irregularly irregular rhythm, not regular tachycardia.
•    D. Sinus tachycardia: Always narrow complex, unless BBB is present (rare with this rate).

questions.text: A 26-year-old trauma patient presents with hypotension, cold clammy skin, and tachycardia. Neck veins are flat. Extremities are cold. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is low. What is the most likely type of shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hypovolemic
Explanation: Cold extremities + hypotension + low PCWP + flat JVP = classic hypovolemic shock.
•    A. Cardiogenic shock: Would show elevated PCWP and JVP.
•    B. Obstructive: (e.g., tamponade, PE) would have elevated JVP.
•    D. Distributive (e.g., septic): Warm extremities and low SVR.

questions.text: A 40-year-old vegetarian woman presents with fatigue and pallor. CBC shows Hb 8 g/dL, MCV 110 fL. Peripheral smear shows hypersegmented neutrophils. Serum methylmalonic acid is elevated. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Vitamin B12 deficiency
Explanation: Macrocytic anemia + hypersegmented neutrophils + elevated methylmalonic acid = Vitamin B12 deficiency.
•    A. Folate deficiency: Also macrocytic, but MMA is normal.
•    B. Iron deficiency: Microcytic anemia.
•    C. Anemia of chronic disease: Usually normocytic or microcytic, not macrocytic.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with COPD on home oxygen presents with confusion. ABG: pH 7.32, paCO₂ 60 mmHg, HCO₃⁻ 32 mEq/L. What is the primary acid-base disturbance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation
Explanation: Low pH + high pCO₂ = primary respiratory acidosis. Elevated bicarbonate indicates metabolic compensation.
•    A. Metabolic alkalosis: Would have high pH.
•    C. Metabolic acidosis: Would have low bicarb.
•    D. Respiratory alkalosis: Would have low pCO₂ and high pH.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child from a low-income area presents with bleeding gums, irritability, and swollen knees. On exam, there is perifollicular hemorrhage and corkscrew hairs. What is the most likely deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vitamin C
Explanation: Vitamin C deficiency (Scurvy) presents with:
•    Bleeding gums
•    Perifollicular hemorrhage
•    Corkscrew hairs
•    Joint pain due to defective collagen synthesis
•    A. Vitamin A: Night blindness, keratomalacia
•    C. Vitamin D: Rickets, bowing of legs
•    D. Vitamin K: Bleeding but not associated with hair/skin findings

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with chronic alcoholism presents with weakness, confusion, and tremors. Lab values: Na⁺ 136, K⁺ 3.2, Mg²⁺ 0.6 mg/dL. ECG shows prolonged QT interval. Which electrolyte abnormality must be corrected first to prevent refractory hypokalemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Magnesium
Explanation: Hypomagnesemia can cause refractory hypokalemia due to increased renal K⁺ loss. Magnesium deficiency impairs Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase and ROMK channel regulation. Unless Mg²⁺ is corrected, K⁺ repletion will be ineffective.
•    A. Sodium: Normal.
•    B. Calcium: QT prolongation can also be due to hypoCa²⁺, but Mg²⁺ is more relevant here.
•    D. Potassium: Needs correction but will not stabilize unless Mg²⁺ is fixed first.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman complains of heat intolerance, palpitations, and weight loss. On exam, she has tachycardia and a non-tender, enlarged thyroid. TSH is undetectable, and free T4 is elevated. Radioiodine uptake scan shows diffuse increased uptake. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Graves’ disease
Explanation: Diffuse increased uptake on radioactive scan + hyperthyroid symptoms = Graves’ disease. It’s the only cause with diffuse uptake due to TSH-receptor antibodies.
•    A. Toxic multinodular goiter: Patchy uptake.
•    B. Subacute thyroiditis: Decreased uptake.
•    D. Exogenous thyroxine: Suppressed TSH, high T4, but no uptake on scan.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has symmetric joint pain in the hands and morning stiffness lasting over an hour. RF is positive. Anti-CCP is also positive. Which of the following features best differentiates rheumatoid arthritis from systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Erosive joint changes on X-ray
Explanation: RA is erosive, whereas SLE causes non-erosive arthritis. This is a key radiologic difference.
•    A. Symmetric involvement: Seen in both.
•    B. ANA: Positive in both, though more strongly in SLE.
•    D. Morning stiffness: Common in both.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with fever, headache, and a maculopapular rash involving palms and soles. He recently returned from a trekking trip. He has tender regional lymphadenopathy and eschar. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Scrub typhus
Explanation: Scrub typhus (caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi) often presents with:
•    Fever
•    Rash involving palms and soles
•    Eschar (may or may not be seen)
•    Lymphadenopathy
•    History of rural/forested exposure in endemic areas (e.g., South India)
•    A. Leptospirosis: May have conjunctival suffusion, myalgia, but rash is rare.
•    C. Secondary syphilis: Can cause similar rash but typically painless lymphadenopathy and no acute fever.
•    D. Dengue: Usually has retro-orbital pain, rash, bleeding signs—but palmar/plantar rash + eschar + regional exposure favors scrub typhus

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a history of alcohol use presents with jaundice and abdominal distension. Lab results show: AST 145 IU/L, ALT 62 IU/L, ALP 150 IU/L, total bilirubin 6.2 mg/dL, INR 1.9, and low albumin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Alcoholic hepatitis
Explanation:
•    AST:ALT >2:1 is classic for alcoholic hepatitis.
•    Elevated bilirubin and INR suggest liver dysfunction.
•    Low albumin = chronicity.
•    ALT typically <300 in alcoholic hepatitis.
•    B. Viral hepatitis: AST and ALT both would be very high (often >1000).
•    C. Autoimmune hepatitis: ALT predominance, often in younger females, with ANA/ASMA positivity.
•    D. PBC: Female, cholestatic pattern (very high ALP), AMA positive.

choices.text: Crescents with fibrin in Bowman space

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with diabetes presents with edema and frothy urine.BP is 120/80 mmHg.Investigations: proteinuria 5.8 g/day, hypoalbuminemia, normal creatinine. Which renal biopsy finding is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Thickened basement membrane without immune deposits
Explanation: This is classic for diabetic nephropathy:
•    Nephrotic-range proteinuria
•    Basement membrane thickening (seen on EM)
•    No immune complex deposition
•    A. IgA nephropathy: Typically hematuria, not nephrotic syndrome.
•    B. FSGS: Can cause nephrotic syndrome but biopsy shows focal sclerosis, not widespread BM thickening.
•    D. RPGN: Presents with rapidly rising creatinine and crescents, not stable nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with hemoptysis, cough, and hematuria. Chest X-ray shows bilateral alveolar infiltrates. Renal biopsy shows linear IgG deposition along the GBM. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Goodpasture syndrome
Explanation:
•    Pulmonary hemorrhage + hematuria = pulmonary-renal syndrome
•    Linear IgG on biopsy = Goodpasture's
•    Anti-GBM antibodies are diagnostic
•    A. GPA: c-ANCA positive, granulomas, nasal involvement.
•    B. Microscopic polyangiitis: p-ANCA, but no linear IgG.
•    D. SLE: Full-house immune complex deposition, not linear IgG.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents with fatigue and weight loss. CBC: Hb 9 g/dL, WBC 160,000 with left shift, and platelets 450,000. LAP score is low. BCR-ABL fusion gene is positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)
Explanation:
•    Markedly elevated WBC with left shift, low LAP score, and BCR-ABL positivity (Philadelphia chromosome) are diagnostic of CML.
•    B. CLL: Lymphocytosis, not granulocytosis.
•    C. Polycythemia vera: Elevated RBC mass, JAK2 mutation.
•    D. AML: Blasts on peripheral smear, acute presentation.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman with progressive breathlessness is found to have the following PFT results:

•    FEV1: 70% predicted

•    FVC: 68% predicted

•    FEV1 / FVC: 0.88

•    TLC: reduced

•    DLCO: markedly reduced

What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

Explanation:

•    Restrictive pattern = ↓ TLC + normal or ↑ 1FEV1 / FVC

•    DLCO markedly reduced → suggests interstitial lung disease, like IPF

•    Myasthenia would also show restriction, but DLCO is usually normal or mildly reduced

Rule-outs:

•    A. Asthma & C. COPD: Both are obstructive

•    D. Myasthenia gravis: Restrictive pattern but DLCO is preserved

questions.text: A 24-year-old college student presents with dry cough, low-grade fever, and malaise for 6 days. Chest auscultation reveals scattered crackles, and CXR shows diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mycoplasma pneumoniae
Explanation:
This is classic atypical pneumonia:
•    Young age, dry cough, mild symptoms, diffuse interstitial infiltrates point toward Mycoplasma.
•    Often called “walking pneumonia.”
Rule-outs:
•    A. S. pneumoniae: Typically causes lobar pneumonia with high fever, productive cough, and consolidation
•    C. Klebsiella: Common in alcoholics or diabetics, causes lobar pneumonia with currant jelly sputum
•    D. Legionella: More severe illness, often with GI symptoms and hyponatremia

questions.text: A 22 yr old farmer with history to trauma over his left foot while walking barefoot on the fields 3 yr back. He has presented with development of warty growth over the left foot. On doing the biopsy the reports reveals these type of brown colored bodies. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Chromoblastomycosis

Subcutaneous fungal infection due to Phialophora verrucosa species

Clinical feature: verrucous lesion on the exposed sites

Histopathology: presence of brown colored bodies or copper penny bodies or sclerotic bodies or medlar bodies

questions.text: A 24 yr old man had multiple, small hypopigmented macules on the upper chest and back for the last three months. The macules were circular, arranged around follicles and may coalesced to form large sheets. The surface of the macules showed fine scaling. He had similar lesion one year ago which subsided with treatment. The most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pityriasis versicolor

It is a superficial fungal infection due to Malassezia globose/ furfur

questions.text: Permissive hypotension is contraindicated in all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Permissive hypotension is a temporary strategy, and blood pressure should be normalized once hemorrhage control is achieved and the patient is stable. 

•    Key principles are:

o    Restricted fluid resuscitation (crystalloid fluids) until hemorrhage control is achieved. 

o    Targeted blood pressure: Aiming for a lower systolic blood pressure (e.g., 90 mmHg). 

o    Rapid and definitive hemorrhage control: 

o    Prevention/treatment of hypothermia and acidosis: 

•    Indications- 

o    Hemodynamically unstable patients with uncontrolled bleeding

o    Patients with penetrating trauma

•    Contraindicated in: 

o    Traumatic brain injury (TBI) and spinal cord injury: In these cases, maintaining adequate cerebral perfusion pressure is crucial, and permissive hypotension can be detrimental. 

o    Patients with chronic hypertension: These patients may require higher blood pressures to maintain adequate tissue perfusion.

questions.text:
A place was hit by earthquake, an old lady survived but lost all the belongings and her house in the earthquake. She complained of anxiety and constant fear but improved when help was provided. Which of the following is correct?
 A. Condition is Acute Stress Reaction 
 B. She doesn't need to consult a psychiatrist 
C. Fluxoetine is the treatment of choice 
D. Projection is the defence mechanism used
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

After an acute precipitating stress factor (earthquake), development of anxiety symptoms which improved points towards diagnosis of acute stress reaction. We need to give anxiolytics in acute stress reaction like benzodiazepines. SSRI are reserved for chronic cases (that turn out to be PTSD). And consultation by psychiatrist is needed to do crisis intervention and supportive psychotherapy (enhancement of coping skills). Projection is not used here as a defense mechanism. (projection is a psychotic defense that explains delusions)

questions.text: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by his wife after he woke up with paralysis of his right arm. The patient reports that the day before, he had gotten into a verbal altercation with his mother over her intrusiveness in his life. The patient notes that he has always had mixed feelings about his mother, but that people should always respect their mothers above all else. Which of the following diagnoses best fits this patient’s clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Conversion Disorder 

Conversion disorder is characterized by the sudden appearance of often dramatic neurological symptoms that are not associated with the usual diagnostic signs and test results expected for the symptoms being presented. 

Conversion disorder occurs in the context of a psychosocial stressor or an insoluble interpersonal or intrapsychic conflict. 
The psychological distress is not consciously acknowledged, but it is expressed through a metaphorical body dysfunction. 

In this example, the man who is torn between his duty to his mother and his intense anger at her resolved his impulse to hit her by developing a physical paralysis of his right arm.

questions.text: The mother of a 25-year-old man who was diagnosed with AIDS 1 year ago, reports that her son had been doing well until this morning when she observed him sitting up in bed, punching the air and grabbing at insects, although none were present. The patient’s CD4 count is < 100 cells/mm3 and his temperature is 103°F. The mother is concerned about these symptoms because the patient’s elder brother has schizophrenia. This clinical picture is most consistent with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Delirium 

This clinical picture that includes the sudden onset of a psychiatric symptom (i.e., visual hallucinations) coinciding with the onset of a high fever in a relatively recently diagnosed (1 year) AIDS patient is most consistent with delirium caused by an opportunistic infection of the brain such as cryptococcal meningitis. 

Psychotic illnesses such as schizophrenia, brief psychotic disorder, or AIDS dementia cannot be diagnosed if the symptoms (as in this patient) can be explained by an acute medical illness. Also, AIDS dementia occurs in the late stages of the disease and would be characterized primarily by gradually worsening cognitive functioning (e.g., memory loss) as well as motor symptoms.

Engagement occurs at 37 weeks in nulliparous patients and it occurs just before labour in multiparous patient. Then there is descent which is actually a continuous process. It is followed by flexion, internal rotation, crowning, delivery by extension, external rotation and then there is delivery of shoulders and body

questions.text: A rhesus-negative second para has an antibody titre of 4 IU/ml (ICT 1:4) at 8 weeks. Her husband is homozygous rhesus positive. What is the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Repeat the antibody titre in 4 weeks

This patient has antibody titre of 1:4. It means she’s already iso-immunised. Since her titres are less than 1:16, it would be a case of low titres. In such cases we must evaluate ICT every two to four weeks. If ICT titre is rising then do it every two weeks and if it is constant then every four weeks. We must also do usg at one-month interval every time. We must deliver such patience at the end of 37 weeks.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a cause of GnRH independent precocious puberty?

questions.text: A young female presented to you with primary amenorrhoea. Examination revealed normal breast development and absent axillary hair. Pelvic examination showed vaginal opening and clitoromegaly. On ultrasound exam, gonads were visible in the inguinal region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Partial AIS 

Primary amenorrhoea with absent axillary hair would point towards androgen insensitivity syndrome. It is a condition where androgenic receptors are deficient. Since there is clitoromegaly, it would be a case where some receptors are present and hence it is a case of partial AIS. Clitoromegaly is not seen in complete AIS.

Correct Answer (D)

Cardinal ligament

The most important support of uterus is Mackenrodt ligament which is also called as transverse cervical ligament or cardinal ligament. It runs from isthmus to lateral pelvic wall. Round ligament is a weak support of uterus. It causes ante-version and ante-flexion position of uterus. Broad ligament is not a support of uterus.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old adolescent is brought to the emergency department for a new-onset generalized tonic-clonic seizure that occurred while asleep. She was having a sleepover party and had stayed up until 3 am. Around 7 am, her friend found her unresponsive with generalized shaking, her eyes rolled up and open, and foaming at the mouth. The event lasted approximately 2 minutes before self-resolving.
On arrival at the emergency department, the girl is drowsy but arousable. She has otherwise normal neurologic findings. Her mother reports that the adolescent has had several episodes of staring spells over the past few years which she attributed to her daughter ignoring her. Over the past year, she has periodically complained of “spasms” where her hand will suddenly jump or jerk. She denies substance use, recent or intercurrent illnesses, or trauma. There is no family history of seizures.
Of the following, the MOST likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The adolescent in the vignette likely has juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME). Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is a common genetic generalized epilepsy usually presenting in early adolescence. Affected children may have a combination of myoclonic jerks, generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and/or absence seizures. Seizures typically occur in the early morning on waking. Often myoclonic seizures are mistaken for clumsiness; if there is a suspicion of myoclonic seizures, the history should include questions about early morning clumsiness, jitteriness, or dropping objects. The most common triggers for seizures in JME are sleep deprivation, alcohol consumption, stress, and flashing lights.

questions.text: Of the following, the anomaly that occurs during the second half of gestation in Infant of Diabetic Mothers:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Small left colon syndrome
The fetal structural anomalies associated with women with diabetes mellitus typically occur prior to 2 months’ gestation, at the time of organogenesis. Most of these anomalies involve the cardiac and neurological systems and include:
• Cardiac: transposition of the great arteries, ventricular septal defect, atrial septal defect, hypoplastic left heart syndrome, aortic stenosis, coarctation of the aorta
• Neurologic: meningomyelocele, encephalocele, anencephaly. 
Infants are also at risk for caudal regression syndrome, which consists of spinal abnormalities and syringomyelia. Renal anomalies (hydronephrosis, renal agenesis, cystic kidneys) and intestinal atresias can also occur. 
Small left colon syndrome usually occurs during the second half of gestation, after organogenesis is complete. In this syndrome, the diameter of the descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum are smaller than normal. The cause is thought to be related to large changes in maternal and fetal serum glucose concentrations. Affected infants often present with signs of intestinal obstruction, such as bilious emesis and abdominal distention.
